discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
21 = FTP *cleartext; no need to go further

To stop cleartext communication with a web server, you would want to close port 80, which is the standard port for HTTP (cleartext web traffic). However, port 80 is not listed in your options.

From the options given:

A. 21 - FTP (File Transfer Protocol, typically cleartext)
B. 22 - SSH (Secure Shell, encrypted)
C. 443 - HTTPS (HTTP Secure, encrypted)
D. 3389 - RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol)

The correct answer to stop cleartext communication would be:

A. 21 (FTP)

However, since the question specifically mentioned web servers, it's possible there might be a mistake in the options provided, as port 80 (HTTP) would be the most appropriate choice for web server cleartext communication.

questions.question_text: While running a local network security scan, an administrator discovers communication between clients and one of the web servers is happening in cleartext. Company policy requires all communication to be encrypted. Which of the following ports should be closed to stop the cleartext communication?

An application server's power cord was accidentally unplugged. After plugging the cord back in, the server administrator notices some transactions were not written to the disk array.

Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this issue?

discussion.content:
Answer is D:
The power outage likely interrupted the transactional process before the data could be written to the disk array, resulting in the loss of those transactions. It's a common issue when power is suddenly cut off without proper shutdown procedures.

Answer is C.
Absolutely, out-of-band management (OOBM) is a crucial tool for troubleshooting issues with unresponsive servers, especially in remote data center environments. With OOBM, you can remotely access and manage the server's hardware, even if the server's primary operating system is not functioning correctly. This allows you to perform tasks such as power cycling, accessing BIOS settings, and viewing hardware logs without relying on the server's network connectivity or operating system.

questions.question_text: A server in a remote data center is no longer responsive. Which of the following is the BEST solution to investigate this failure?

discussion.content: The verbage states "Which of the following MUST be completed before launching the installation package again?". You do not HAVE to validate the checksum before launching the installation package again, although this is best practice, but you do HAVE to create an exclusion or the AV will still block installation. Answer is A.
The didn't say it was corrupt, they specifically say AV is blocking it. So an AV exclusion is needed, not checksum.

Selected Answer: C
C. Validating the checksum for the downloaded installation package

When downloading packages from the internet, especially for servers, it's crucial to ensure the integrity and authenticity of the package. This helps to ensure that the package hasn't been tampered with and that it's safe to install. The most common way to do this is by checking the checksum of the downloaded file against a known good checksum provided by the software vendor.

Therefore, the best practice in this scenario is:

C. Validating the checksum for the downloaded installation package.

BUT, this question seems to assume the file has Integrity already

choices.D: Checking for corruption of the downloaded installation package
choices.C: Validating the checksum for the downloaded installation package
choices.B: Disabling real-time scanning by the antivirus
choices.A: Creating an exclusion to the antivirus for the application

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is attempting to install a package on a server. After downloading the package from the internet and trying to launch it, the installation is blocked by the antivirus on the server. Which of the following must be completed before launching the installation package again?
An administrator needs to increase the size of an existing RAID 6 array that is running out of available space. Which of the following is the BEST way the administrator can perform this task?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
By replacing the drives one at a time and allowing the array to rebuild after each replacement, you can gradually increase the size of the array without losing data. Once all drives have been replaced, you can then expand the array to make use of the additional space. This approach minimizes the risk of data loss compared to replacing all drives at once.

I am curious, don't the hard drives in the RAID have to be the same size (and ideally the same make) before we can build an array? If we have to replace one at a time, won't that mess the RAID configuration up?

choices.D: Replace the array drives one at a time and then expand the array.
choices.B: Expand the array by changing the RAID level to 6.
choices.C: Expand the array by changing the RAID level to 10.
choices.A: Replace all the array drives at once and then expand the array.
